urn:contentItem:6FNV-F2T3-S5RX-61BK-00000-00SMITH MEETS FIREFIGHTERS, LOCAL OFFICIALS, RESIDENTS2025-04-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisSMITH MEETS FIREFIGHTERS, LOCAL OFFICIALS, RESIDENTS

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Rep. Chris Smith issued the following news:

Rep. Chris Smith (R-NJ) joined firefighters from the New Jersey Forest Fire Service today at the site of the Jones Road Wildfire, which has so far ravaged over 15,000 acres in Southern Ocean County.

"The work of the firefighters has been amazing," Smith said. "These men and women have fought and are continuing to fight until this wildfire is out. They have certainly saved many homes and businesses-and lives-by steering the fire away from populated areas. Still, the fire crossed the Parkway and Route 9 and even reached some bulkheads on Barnegat Bay before it was stopped. The firefighters have worked long and hard, but are absolutely determined."

Smith said firefighters said they were counting on as much rain as possible Saturday to help douse the blaze, which is about 60 percent contained, but were wary of Sunday's expected winds, predicted to be gusts of 40 mph, which threaten to rekindle some areas and keep crews very busy. One firefighter said that on Sunday it would be "all hands on deck."

Smith surveyed areas of the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, electric high towers, and the Garden State Parkway and Route 9, where the fire skipped over both roads to threaten homes to the east before being stopped at the water's edge of Barnegat Bay just past South Main Street in Lacey Township.

He also stopped at the Liberty Door and Awning business, the only known main structure to be destroyed by the blaze. He consoled and offered assistance to the owner, Bob Nosti. Smith was joined by State Sen. Carmen Amato, Lacey Mayor Pete Curatolo and former Committeeman Mark Dycoff. Only a few blackened support beams remained standing through a pile twisted metal and charred debris. The congressman also met with reporters covering the blaze at the business on Old Shore Road.

Smith noted the Trump Administration quickly okayed a request by the State of New Jersey to be approved to apply for future funding through FEMA's Fire Management Assistance Grant (FMAG). FEMA informed him of the approval Friday. Additionally, he was informed Friday by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that though the plant had been threatened by the blaze at one point, it was now secure.

"The Trump Administration acted quickly so the community can recover, for which I am grateful," Smith said. "In the weeks and months ahead, State, County and local governments can now seek this grant to reimburse the costs of fighting this fire. It will take a full effort by all levels of government to beat this fire and make the communities whole."

urn:contentItem:6FNV-F2T3-S5RX-61BN-00000-00SMITH WELCOMES FEDS' OFFER OF SUPPORT FOR NJ STATE AND LOCAL FIREFIGHTERS BATTLING THE WILDFIRE2025-04-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisSMITH WELCOMES FEDS' OFFER OF SUPPORT FOR NJ STATE AND LOCAL FIREFIGHTERS BATTLING THE WILDFIRE

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Rep. Chris Smith issued the following news:

Rep. Chris Smith (R-NJ) today commended the Trump Administration for its fast review and determination to make federal dollars accessible as State and local agencies tabulate the costs incurred in battling and recovering from the Jones Road Wildfire which has ravaged more than 15,000 acres in Southern Ocean County.

"At this very moment our firefighters, led by the New Jersey Forest Fire Service (NJFFS), are holding the line on this massive wildfire and are working tirelessly to protect lives, homes, businesses and other structures across Southern Ocean County," Smith said. "The fire is only 60 percent contained, so they will be working into the weekend and using more resources to extinguish the blaze and mitigate the damage.

"I thank President Trump and his Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), for acting quickly to give a green light for grant assistance-an absolutely critical first step to securing federal funding to respond to this emergency," Smith said.

Smith said he was advised by FEMA of the approved eligibility for a federal Fire Management Assistance Grant (FMAG) declaration. The approval allows State and local government to apply for reimbursement at 75 percent federal cost share for eligible expenses, such as the cost of equipment and supplies (less any insurance reimbursement); sheltering; police barricading and traffic control; field camps and meals; arson investigation; cost of items for firefighter health and safety; and mobilization and demobilization. Details of the grant can be found here.

Smith said that Acting Regional Administrator for FEMA Region 2 (New York Region) Andrew D'Amora, determined that the Jones Road Fire threatened enough possible destruction as could constitute a major disaster. The early days of the fire saw an estimated 1,859 homes at risk. Also threatened was Oyster Creek Generating Station, high tension power lines, travel on Route 9 and Garden State Parkway, Lacey Industrial Park, and hundreds of businesses in the area. About 3,000 mandatory/voluntary evacuations were issued for approximately 3,000 people. As of Friday morning, all evacuated residents were allowed to return to their homes, the evacuation order was lifted, and one commercial business destroyed. Oyster Creek was reported to be secure by its owner, Holtec, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

"We are deeply grateful to our courageous firefighters and other first responders who are working around the clock to contain the wildfire," Smith said. "It is only fitting that the federal government step up quickly as a financial partner, ensuring that our local heroes are fortified with the equipment, supplies and other support systems needed to get the job done." urn:contentItem:6FPD-9973-S15F-82KV-00000-00Pallone Slams Trump Admin for Withholding Accurate Forecasts as Pine Barrens Burn2025-04-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisPallone Slams Trump Admin for Withholding Accurate Forecasts as Pine Barrens BurnTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Rep. Frank Pallone Jr., D-New Jersey, issued the following news release:

* * *

Pallone Slams Trump Admin for Withholding Accurate Forecasts as Pine Barrens Burn

Washington, DC - Congressman Frank Pallone, Jr. (NJ-06), the top Democrat on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, today revealed deeply troubling dysfunction inside the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) that threatens the agency's ability to alert public safety agencies to extreme weather - even as wildfires rage in New Jersey's Pine Barrens.

NOAA research labs like Princeton's Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL) are being forced to slash vital forecasting operations due to staffing cuts and an outrageous new Trump Administration policy requiring NOAA expenditures - from individual scientists' employment contracts down to electricity and internet bills - be personally approved by Trump's Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick.

"This absurd micromanagement is designed to kill off the federal agency tasked with trying to understand and respond to our changing environment and preserve our natural resources," Pallone said. "And while the Pine Barrens burn, the people who protect us are being starved of the data they need to act."

As a result of funding delays and job losses across NOAA's research arms, national labs like GFDL have been forced to scale back their contributions to the North American Multi-Model Ensemble (link is external) (NMME) database. The seasonal forecasts--used to predict drought, temperature, and rainfall--will only have accurate data once per quarter, instead of each month. Emergency planners, including the New Jersey Forest Fire Service, received their last complete data set in April. New data was expected tomorrow, May 1, but due to the Trump Administration's restrictions, it won't arrive. The next update isn't expected until July.

"These reports help public safety agencies and first responders prepare for drought conditions that can spark fires like the one engulfing Lacey Township right now," Pallone continued. "Without them, communities are flying blind."

Pallone placed the blame squarely on the Trump Administration's deliberate sabotage of climate science and emergency preparedness. NOAA contracts and grants--many essential to keeping research labs operating--are stuck in Secretary Lutnick's inbox awaiting his personal approval. Postdoctoral researchers at NOAA labs are now receiving 60-day termination notices as their contracts approach expiration in June.

"Lutnick can't even keep up with Trump's tariff disaster, and now he's supposed to personally approve NOAA's utility bills?" Pallone said. "This guy is juggling trade talks with imaginary countries while American scientists are getting pink slips. It's a circus and Jersey is paying the price."

Pallone reiterated his call for the immediate release of frozen funds and restoration of normal NOAA operations. On April 16, he led New Jersey's Democratic Congressional Delegation in a letter to Secretary Lutnick demanding stable Fiscal Year 2026 funding and an immediate reversal of staffing cuts, funding freezes, and program terminations.

urn:contentItem:6FKB-5XW3-RVFB-G11H-00000-00'Nobody stays behind,' cat sanctuary shares new fire safety plan2025-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexis'Nobody stays behind,' cat sanctuary shares new fire safety planBy Noah Caplan(KOAA)

Click here for updates on this story

BLACK FOREST, Colorado (KOAA) -- It's a place for southern Colorado's "under-served" felines.

"Any cat that just needs a soft place to land... they're gonna find a home here," said Wild Blue Cats Outreach Director Sabrina Utter.

Utter said the sanctuary, which is home to both cats being made ready for adoption and cats that are better off in an outdoor environment, has grown quite a bit in recent years.

Utter said the Black Forest Fire came within a mile of the sanctuary's property.

"Everybody was gathering cats, the problem was in 2013, we didn't have an evacuation plan," said Utter.

Responding to the fire, Utter said Wild Blue's volunteers came up with a detailed plan.

She said it's a plan that assigns people to every main area of the sanctuary, with equipment ready to go that makes it easy for volunteers to catch the cats and get them to safety. One of those gadgets she called an "easy nabber."

"It's like a giant clam shell made of mesh. And so if you have to, you can do that," she said, when talking about the cats.

One of the unique parts about Wild Blue is its 100 by 200 foot fenced in an area known as Maya's Wildheart Village. It's currently home to 29 cats who are not meant to be in a home and can live their lives safely and comfortably.

But since these cats are feral, it can be very hard for volunteers or even firefighters to corral them in the event of an emergency. Utter said the best way to keep them safe is by cutting the netting to the enclosure.

"The plan is to, like, snip the fence in multiple places so that they can escape," she added.

But, the best way to keep these guys safe in the event of fire, Utter said, is to find the indoor cats a loving home.

"The biggest challenge with adoption is education," she said. "Making 100% sure that person that (whoever) adopts them knows what the challenges are going to be."

urn:contentItem:6FP3-FW73-SHSV-13XM-00000-00New Jersey Wildfire 75% Contained; Crews to Remain on Scene Until 'Significant' Rain2025-04-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisNew Jersey Wildfire 75% Contained; Crews to Remain on Scene Until 'Significant' Rain

The New Jersey Forest Fire Service reported continued progress in fighting the Jones River wildfire, with the fire being 75% contained by noon on Monday, April 28.

Officials said crews will remain on the scene for the next several days to continue to improve containment lines and address areas of concern "until significant precipitation occurs" to ensure public safety.

The fire has burned 15,300-acres in the Ocean County Natural Lands Trust's Forked River Mountains Wilderness Area.

A Waretown man has been charged with arson in connection with the blaze.

No injuries have been reported. About four structures remain under threat. One commercial building has been destroyed and multiple outbuildings and vehicles have been damaged. A complete damage assessment is in process.

The fire service repeated a warning from the National Weather Service that there is an increased risk for rapid fire spread across most of New Jersey and Delaware due to low humidity values and northwest winds 15 to 20 mph with 30 mph gusts. "These conditions, along with the continued drying of fine fuels, could support the rapid spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control," the service warned.

Officials said that smoke is expected to remain present until significant rain falls over the fire area. Visitors to the area have been advised to exercise caution as trees within the fire area may be weakened.

The fire was first spotted on April 22 at the Cedar Bridge Fire Tower at 9:45 a.m. That evening, the wildfire crossed the Garden State Parkway, leading to the evacuation of approximately 5,000 residents in Ocean and Lacey townships. Additionally, Route 9 and Route 532 (Wells Mills Road) were closed early on in the firefight.

Update on New Jersey Wildfire: Suspect Charged With Arson

New Jersey officials announced last Wednesday that a 19-year old man has been charged with arson in connection with the wildfire. Joseph Kling of Waretown failed to properly extinguish a bonfire of wooden pallets, according to state and county officials. They said an investigation revealed that Kling set wooden pallets on fire - and then left the area without the fire being fully extinguished.

According to officials, Kling was taken into custody and then transported to the Ocean County jail, where he is awaiting a detention hearing.

Like all defendants, Kling is presumed innocent unless and until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt in a court of law.

Forecast Calls for Wildfires to Burn More Land Across US This Year

A recent report by AccuWeather says that abnormally dry conditions and warm weather could boost the fire danger along the Eastern Seaboard through the rest of this spring. The spring fire risk on the East Coast extends as far south as parts of southern Florida, according to the forecast.

urn:contentItem:6FDH-YFV3-RRV2-X071-00000-00Fires are raging across North and South Carolina—and the coming weather could make them worse2025-03-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisFires are raging across North and South Carolina—and the coming weather could make them worseAssociated Press

Firefighters in North and South Carolina were battling multiple wind-driven wildfires Monday in rugged terrain that complicated containment efforts, officials said.

Millions of trees knocked down by Hurricane Helene last year combined with long stretches of dry weather this spring are making for a long and active fire season in the Carolinas, North Carolina State University forestry and environmental resources professor Robert Scheller said.

“Helene just dropped tons of fuel on the ground,” Scheller said. “Then these flash droughts allow that fuel to dry out very fast.”

Both South Carolina and North Carolina have issued statewide bans on outdoor burning.

North Carolina fires

Mandatory evacuations continue for about 165 properties in parts of Polk County in western North Carolina, about 80 miles west of Charlotte, according to county spokesperson Kellie Cannon.

Three fires burned at least 7.5 square miles in the county and the two larger blazes were completely uncontained, Cannon said in a social media update Monday morning. The Black Cove Fire, one of the larger ones, was moving toward neighboring Henderson County, Cannon said.

Kim Callaway, who lives near one of the evacuated areas in Polk County, has prepared her home, WLOS-TV reported.

“We’ve already actually evacuated everything that we thought that was important,” Callaway said. “And now we’re just staying at the house and trying to do what we can to get our house prepared if the firemen need to show up and hold the line.”

A downed power line sparked the Black Cove Fire, but the causes of the other two fires in Polk County were under investigation, according to North Carolina Forest Service spokesperson Jeremy Waldrop.

A number of other wildfires are burning across the state, including one that damaged 500 vehicles at a salvage yard in Burke County, officials said.

South Carolina fires

Two fires in the South Carolina mountains have led Governor Henry McMaster to declare a state of emergency.

One fire was in Table Rock State Park in Pickens County and the other was on Persimmon Ridge in Greenville County. Winds and difficult mountainous terrain allowed blazes to grow, the South Carolina Forestry Commission said.

The Table Rock Fire expanded to more than 2 square miles, including several hundred acres that firefighters intentionally burned to try to contain the flames, officials said.

The Persimmon Ridge Fire, which started Saturday, spread to more than 1.25 square miles despite many dozens of water drops, the commission said.

Human activity ignited both the Table Rock and Persimmon Ridge fires. No injuries had been reported, and while no structures were imminently threatened, voluntary evacuations of about 100 homes remained in place.

How a September hurricane is creating March fires

Scheller, the North Carolina State University professor, predicted this busy fire season if the region saw dry weather following Helene.

Scientists saw something similar in 2022 when a fire burned more than 51 square miles of timberland in the Florida Panhandle. The Bertha Swamp Road Fire almost directly followed the eye pattern from 2018’s Hurricane Michael and the fallen pine trees left behind.

Pines and their waxy needles dry out and become very flammable, Scheller said. The fallen trunks can also block roads and paths used to fight fires, experts said.

The last ingredient to fuel wildfires is dry weather. Despite recent rain, the Carolinas are undergoing an extreme drought, according to federal monitors.

The common denominator for many fires on the East Coast is human activity, whether people burn debris, light a campfire that isn’t well watched, or toss out cigarette, Scheller said.

And more people living next to areas that can burn make fires a bigger threat, he said.

New Jersey fire

A forest fire burning in New Jersey’s million-acre Pinelands region was 100% contained on Monday morning, the New Jersey Forest Fire Services said in a post on X. The fire was first spotted Saturday and burned through about 3.5 square miles.

That blaze led authorities to evacuate two campgrounds in Wharton State Forest, officials said. The cause was under investigation.

Fire forecast

A front moving off the East Coast brought rain and more humidity to the area, helping firefighters Monday.

But not much rain fell, and temperatures are expected to get warmer and the air drier as the week goes on, likely meaning another round of wildfires unless people follow burn bans and fire safety.

“It is absolutely paramount that folks respect the statewide ban on all open burning,” North Carolina Forest Service spokesperson Philip Jackson said.

Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

The essential need to identify the most informative sources of greenhouse gas emissions (climate change drivers) impacting the food security nexus in Africa requires a comprehensive and holistic approach. Machine learning method excels in the identification of single-variable importance, our study complements their abilities by deriving principal components using principal component analysis (PCA) to give a significant understanding of the three primary greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide (CO₂), methane (CH₄), and nitrous oxide (N₂O)). We used data from FAO concerning Africa from 2000 to 2021. Food household consumption emission (CH₄), burning crop residues (N₂O), and food transport (N₂O) are the key variables identified by machine learning as critical contributors to climate change drivers impacting food security. Biomass-burning emissions factor, land management emissions factor, and food supply chain emissions factor are the key principal components after subjecting the 86 to PCA. Focusing on the variables and the factors revealed by the extreme gradient, random forest, and PCA can help stakeholders develop efficient practices like promoting sustainable crop residue management and a sustainable food system that reduces post-harvest loss. Our study did not consider the potential impact of spatial effect in the identification of the key sources of greenhouse gases impacting food security, we will explore this in future works.

IntroductionIn Africa, several individuals suffering from food insecurity and malnutrition have severely impacted health education and economic growth making people more susceptible to food insecurity. Increasing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions has also negatively increased the climate variability concerning agricultural produce, leading to the attraction of researchers to investigate the relationship between climate change and food insecurity1. Even though the climate of the earth has been changing for the past millions of years current indicator indicates a rapidly changing rate and researchers are in agreement it is due to human activities2,3. These human activities have led to heatwaves, heavy rains, and protracted droughts as a result of greenhouse gases(drivers of climate change) emissions such as carbon dioxide (CO₂), methane (CH₄), and nitrous oxide (N₂O)4. In particular, the human activities associated with industrial growth and agriculture practices are the major contributors to these emissions in Africa5.

The rising food security has been associated with climate-related factors globally6. The four main pillars(accessibility, availability, utilization, and stability ) of food security as specified by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) are significantly affected by CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O7 This is apparent in the impact of extreme weather events affecting several facets of livelihoods such degrade the nutritional value of crops, health, and food security2. Adesete, Olanubi8 support this by highlighting the difficulties associated with achieving the four primary pillars of food security due to environmental complications. Africa may be more susceptible to food security due to substantial dependence on climate-sensitive agricultural systems and low ability to adjust to climatic shocks9,10. Africa’s already limited natural and environmental resources are under tremendous strain due to climate change. Food instability, widespread undernourishment, malnutrition, frequent maternal mortality, and dietary inadequacies are among the ongoing issues caused by the enormous strain on forests, land, water, air, biodiversity, and ecosystem services8.

Although numerous studies6,11,12 have investigated the effects of climate change on the food and agricultural sectors, other literature13,14 have investigated the effects of climate change on the food and agricultural sectors, other literature. In order to attain all four pillars (availability, accessibility, utilization, and stability), it is necessary to investigate the specific greenhouse gas sources that influence food insecurity. In the context of Africa, this area remains underexplored, to the best of our knowledge.

Researchers15,16 can identify important factors of food insecurity by using machine learning to reveal intricate correlations within large datasets. Machine learning makes it possible to mine several complex correlations existing within the data17, this makes it convenient for identifying the most informative source for greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions concerning Africa’s food security. In the presence of multicollinearity, Machine learning methods fail to capture significant underlying structures within the data despite their ability to prioritize variables effectively18. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) creates variables that combine the related variable impact to explain the significant variation within the data based on a statistical learning framework19. Hence, we combine machine learning and PCA (statistical learning) to identify the most informative source of climate change drivers (CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O) concerning Africa’s food security.

According to the literature20, which assessed 91 studies, research on food security has mostly concentrated on household levels, frequently ignoring regional perspectives in the context of Africa and lacking statistical modeling. To tackle this issue, Bofa and Zewotir21 created elements that cover each of the four pillars of food security within the African setting. However, climate-related variables were not taken into account in their studies. According to recent estimates, the global food system is responsible for almost one-third of greenhouse gas emissions8,22,23.

To achieve Sustainable Development Goals, especially in the African context it is essential to identify the significant sources of CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O to facilitate efficient solutions to guarantee public health safety for a better grasp of the connections between climate change and food security. It is also vital to develop and incorporate composite factors that integrate the main sources of greenhouse gas (CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O)24 to broadly understand their collective influence on food security in Africa using statistical learning. We apply machine learning and PCA to identify the main sources of greenhouse gas emissions associated with food security in Africa as the selection of food security indicators has relied on subjective judgment20 by experts rather than a statistical learning framework.

Complementing machine learning models with PCA provides an advantage to the challenges associated with complex and high-dimensional datasets. Using variable importance, the machine learning models identify key sources of CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O (greenhouse gas) about food security whereas the PCA accounts for a significant variation within the complete data by linking related components to capture wider trends. This is essential for policymakers and stakeholders to enable targeted actions such as incentivizing sustainable practices for key variables(sources) and sharing data and strategies among African countries to curb the emission of greenhouse gases. Again, this procedure can be applied to other areas which may include epidemiology, healthcare, and finance where similar high-dimensional data challenges may arise.

Data and statistical methods

A key component in assessing the sources of greenhouse gases in connection with food security concerning Africa is a reliable data source. Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) plays an essential role in the provision of data for global food and agriculture dynamics. This research utilized data from the FAO, including meta-information, covering the period from 2000 to 2021 for Africa, resulting in a total of 1187 observations available at https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/GT (Retrieved in November 2024). As evidenced by earlier research25, 26–27 our data comprised 86 variables that represented the sources of greenhouse gases for methane (CH₄), nitrous oxide (N₂O), and carbon dioxide (CO₂) as drivers of climate change. As indicated in Table S1, the 86 variables were given specific names to simplify the analysis. The methodology is summarized in Fig. 1, and the variables (sources) and their designated names are included in Table S1. A valuable metric for assessing food security is the frequency of persons who are in the severe food insecurity category28. When individuals are experiencing hunger and are at serious risk of running out of food, in most extreme cases going days without eating, then severe food insecurity has occurred28. Hence the explanatory variable for this study is the number of individuals who are severely food insecure in Africa.

Fig. 1

Data description and preprocessing workflow for the identification of key sources of greenhouse gases in Africa. Summary of the data description and processing steps, including data source and relevance to food security; handling missing values; application of machine learning methods; use of principal component analysis; selection of most informative sources of greenhouse gases.

Handling missing values

We used the Amelia approach29 for multiple imputations with R version 4.4.2. By using the expectation-maximization with the bootstrapping procedure to each of the m (the number of imputations) bootstrap samples, this method creates several credible datasets for additional analysis. Across the bootstrap samples, the m estimates of means and variances will differ. Using regression, the first set of estimates is used to impute the first set of missing values first, then the second set of estimates for the second set of missing values, and so this process continues. As a result of this procedure, several imputed datasets are produced, which capture the uncertainty and variability of the missing data. Making it an exceptionally versatile tool for managing complex data structures30,31. A total of 10 imputed datasets were created to address missing data, aligning with the commonly recommended range of 5 to 10 imputations for moderate levels of missingness. All subsequent analyses were conducted using pooled estimates, which appropriately incorporate both within- and between-imputation variability32,33.

Machine learning methods

Random Forest (RF) an ensemble learning technique creates several decision trees that are constructed using various data subsets. Using bootstrapping decision trees are separately trained using several training subsets. The outputs of each tree are averaged to produce the final prediction. The mean decrease in accuracy metric is used to determine the variable importance34,35.

Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) is an advanced boosting algorithm that sequentially constructs trees, fixing errors from earlier trees utilizing regularization (LASSO or Ridge) to avoid overfitting. The model initiates by making a simple prediction concerning the mean outcome for a weak model. Then new trees are trained iteratively based on the previous model to minimize the residual errors36.

For the Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM) approach, weak learners (decision trees) gradually minimize the residual error associated with the previous. This is achieved by the combination of weak learners with strong learners to improve prediction accuracy. The degree to which each variable raises the accuracy of the model determines its relative importance35,37.

The Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm selects a suitable kernel function (Linear, Polynomial, or Radial Basis Function) for the impute space transformation after scaling to standardize variables. It then constructs an optimal hyperplane that minimizes error in the regression tasks35,38,39.

K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) assigns predictions based on a distance-based algorithm using similarities between data points after normalizing features to ensure fair distance calculations. With cross-validation, the optimal number of neighbors (K) is determined. The target point’s Euclidean distance from its closest neighbors is calculated for predictions. The final estimate(prediction) is determined by averaging the values of the neighbors40.

Concerning Neural Network (NN) the input, hidden, and output layers make up the network’s structure, and each neuron uses an activation function like Sigmoid. Backpropagation is used to modify the weights after they are randomly allocated. Optimization algorithms such as gradient descent are then used to determine and minimize the error41.

Using the most informative features the Decision Tree (DT) split the dataset to enable the creation of a hierarchical structure for estimation(prediction). Using the best attribute for data splitting at each node, the tree is constructed, and this continues up until the criterion for stopping (e.g., maximum depth or minimum sample split) is reached. While reducing overfitting, pruning techniques are applied. From root to leaf, the tree is traversed to make predictions42.

Model evaluation

We utilised 10-fold cross-validation for effective model validation. After the data was divided into 10 folds the model was trained on 10 − 1 folds and tested on the remaining fold. The process continued 10 times until all folds were used as a test set once to ensure that the model was capable of generalizing for unseen data. During this, the root mean square error (RMSE) and mean absolute error (MAE) were computed as the evaluation metrics. The RMSE is given as

Principal component analysis

As a dimensional reduction method for preserving many variations in the data, it begins by standardizing the data to have a mean zero and a standard deviation of one. Then the relationship between variables is captured by the computation of the covariance matrix. Next, the eigenvalues, which measure the variance captured by each principal component, and the eigenvector, which indicates the direction of these components, are computed. The top j eigenvectors are selected to form the principal component as the eigenvalues are sorted in descending order43. Readers are referred to Bofa and Zewotir21 for a detailed mathematical formulation. Using the Pearson correlation coefficient, the principal component that accounts for at least 75% of the variation was named depending on the level of correlation associated with the original dataset44. An absolute value of 0.5 for Pearson’s correlation45 was applied to aid in the naming of significant components. This ensures that extracted components reflect a well-defined underlying construct45.

Results

In this section, the PCA and machine learning models are presented in figures to identify key sources of greenhouse gases concerning food security in Africa. Missing values were handled after it was assessed to enable complete data to facilitate the cross-validation of models, and their performance evaluation using RMSE and MAE.

The distribution of the missingness revealed that the proportion of incomplete was 9% while 91% was complete. To ensure that the rate of missingness does not affect the accuracy of our analysis significantly, we applied Multiple imputations to make the data complete (Fig. 2).

Random forest comes in second (RMSE: 1.958, MAE: 0.828) making it a strong alternative. Principal component analysis

Fig. 4

The x-axis indicates the principal components and the y-axis represents the cumulative percentage of total variance explained. The elbow point, where the curve begins to plateau, indicates the optimal number of components to retain for dimensionality reduction while preserving the majority of the dataset’s variability.

As we subjected the 86 variables to our data reduction technique, 16 principal components were selected, accounting for 86% of the variation in the data, which is evident in Fig. 4 .

Using the cumulative variance threshold approach, we retained components that collectively accounted for approximately 75% of the total variance in the dataset. To support this selection, a scree plot (Fig. 4) was employed to visually determine the point where the eigenvalue slope begins to flatten, indicating diminishing returns in the variance explained by additional components. The identified “elbow” in the plot justified the retention of 16 components33. Using Pearson´s correlation (Fig. 5) the 16 principal components were assigned names at a threshold of the absolute value of 0.5 correlation: Biomass Burning factor, Livestock and Energy emission factor, Agricultural Land emission factor, Fire emission Factor, Food Supply Chain emissions factor, Land Management emission factor, Land-Use Change factor, Household emissions factor, Crop Residues factor, On-Farm emission factor, Synthetic fertilizer emission factor, Agri-food Systems factor, Waste-Related missions factor, Farm and Soil Fire emissions factor, Forest fire emission, Crop emission factor.

Due to the potential impact of possible correlation among variables, sixteen principal components were derived and named based on the variables most strongly associated with each principal component (Fig. 5). PC1 named Biomass burning emission factor is strongly associated with variables such as enteric fermentation (CO₂ and CH₄), fires in humid tropical forests (CO₂), food retail (CO₂), farm gate (CO₂), land use change (N₂O), waste (CO₂), burning - crop residues (CO₂), and agrifood systems (N₂O), all with a correlation coefficient of 0.8. Livestock and Energy emission factor (PC2) is correlated (0.8) with enteric fermentation (CO₂), energy (N₂O), emissions from livestock (CO₂), pesticides manufacturing (CO₂), manure left on pasture (N₂O), and food transport (N₂O). Agricultural land factor (PC3) with a correlation coefficient of 0.8, is linked to emissions on agricultural land (CH₄ and CO₂), farm gate (CH₄), and energy (CH₄). Forest fires (N₂O), fires in humid tropical forests (CO₂ and CH₄), and agrifood systems waste disposal (CO₂) are associated with the Fire emission factor (PC4) with a correlation of 0.7. All these variables associated with the Biomass burning emission factor, the Livestock, and the Energy emission factor, the Agricultural land factor, and the Fire emission factor.

At a correlation of 0.7, the food supply chain emissions factor (PC5) is related to food transport (N₂O), pre- and post-production (N₂O), other (CO₂), and net forest conversion (CO₂). Land Management emission factor (PC6) is related to variables such as manure management (CO₂), Emissions from livestock (N₂O), and AFOLU (CO₂), all with a correlation coefficient of 0.8. Land-use Change factor (PC7) is strongly associated with variables such as LULUCF (CH₄) and Land Use Change (CO₂), both with a correlation of 0.5. The household emission factor (PC8) is also at a correlation of 0.5 with food household consumption (CO₂) and burning-crop residues (CH₄). Concerning the crop residues factor (PC9) it is related to crop residues (CO₂), agrifood systems (CH₄), and LULUCF (N₂O) with a correlation coefficient of 0.5. A similar correlation coefficient of 0.5 was recorded for the on-farm emission factor (PC10) which is related to on-farm energy use (CO₂), and manure management (N₂O).

Synthetic fertilizer emission factor (PC11) was correlated (0.8) to Synthetic Fertilizers (CH₄) and AFOLU (CH₄). Agrifood systems emission factor (PC12) was associated with LULUCF (CH₄) and agrifood systems (N₂O) with a correlation of 0.8, waste-related emissions factor (PC13) is linked to food transport (CO₂) and agrifood systems waste disposal (N₂O), Farm and Soil fire emissions factor (PC14) linked to farm gate (N₂O) and fires in organic soils (CH₄), Forest fire emission factor (PC15) is related to forest fires (N₂O) and synthetic fertilizers (N₂O) and Crops emissions factor (PC16) is associated with forest fires (N₂O) and emissions from crops. PC 14, PC15, and PC16 were all with a correlation coefficient of 0.6.

MAE and RMSE for random forest and gradient boosting models applied to the principal components. Boxplots of MAE and RMSE for random forest and gradient boosting. The black dots represent the mean error values, while the boxes and whiskers indicate the spread of errors across multiple runs.

Since the random forest (RF) and extreme gradient boosting models exhibited similar performance in RMSE and MAE, they were further applied to the principal components to assess their effectiveness in capturing the most important variables. The results for RMSE and MAE (Fig. 6) revealed that the RF is the best model for the identification of important principal components, even though there was not much deviation in that of the extreme gradient boosting. Figure 7 represents the variable importance of both models as the best two-rank model in the first stage of the analysis of this study.

Fig. 7

Variable importance in random forest and extreme gradient boosting for the principal components. Darker shades indicate higher importance, highlighting the key sources of greenhouse gases impacting food security in Africa.

Biomass burning emission is the most important variable in both models. Land management emissions and Crop residue emissions also hold importance across both models. Other notable variables include food supply chain emissions, fire emissions, and land-use change emissions, while there are similarities in the ranking of important variables, slight differences exist in how the models weigh them.

Discussion

The focus of this study was to explore machine learning and statistical learning techniques to identify the key driver (greenhouse gas) of climate change relating to food security. The predictive performance of the seven machine learning models was assessed while the PCA derived a set of components that represent the three main sources (carbon dioxide (CO₂), methane (CH₄), and nitrous oxide (N₂O)) of greenhouse gases46.

The extreme gradient boosting model had the lowest RMSE (1.928) and MAE (0.798), with the random forest being the closest (Table 1). This is in line with a previous study that highlighted the superior predictive capabilities of these models in dealing with large data47. These two models exhibited remarkably nearly identical predictive performance with a negligible difference of 0.03 in both RMSE and MAE after cross-validation, underscoring that they are very similar in their predictability concerning the relation in the data. However, since RMSE places slightly greater emphasis on large errors due to its squaring of residuals, the extreme gradient boosting is considered marginally better as it is less likely to produce large prediction errors for food security in Africa. Random forest and extreme gradient boosting can be regarded as strong alternatives for each other as their performance is practically indistinguishable in terms of overall accuracy, making them a viable choice for predictive tasks, with the decision potentially guided by factors like interpretability. This is evident from the paired permutation test33, which showed that the mean differences in performance metrics (MAE and RMSE) between the two models were not statistically significant (p-value = 0.13) at the α = 0.05 level.

The first stage of our analysis revealed the 10 most important sources of climate change drivers in Africa from the 86 bulk sources obtained from FAO. They are burning crop residues (N₂O), burning crop residues(CO₂), enteric fermentation(CO₂), manure management (N₂O), synthetic fertilizers(N₂O), food household consumption (CH₄), farm gate(CH₄), land use change (N₂O), Emissions from crop(CO₂), and Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry LULUCF(CH₄).These 10 sources were reported in previous studies48, 49, 50–51 as a major cause of climate change resulting in unpredictable weather patterns such as droughts and floods that disrupt crop yields leading to food insecurity.

In the second stage, the random forest model outperformed its competing counterpart. The analysis revealed three significant factors, meeting the 75% (first quartile) threshold: biomass-burning emissions, land management emissions, and food supply chain emissions. Biomass burning emissions factor entail fermentation (CO₂ and CH₄), fires in humid tropical forests (CO₂), food retail (CO₂), farm gate (CO₂), land use change (N₂O), waste (CO₂), burning - crop residues (CO₂), and agrifood systems (N₂O). Land management emissions factor encompasses manure management (CO₂), Emissions from livestock (N₂O), and AFOLU (CO₂). The food supply chain emissions factor is linked to food transport (N₂O), pre-and post-production (N₂O), other (CO₂), and net forest conversion (CO₂). These findings align with a literature review report by Chataut, Bhatta51 and Raza, Abid48. These factors are very likely to lead to soil degradation and reduce arable land, coupled with the food waste in the supply chain, which exacerbates food insecurity52,53. Policymakers and stakeholders can now prioritize the variables identified by the extreme gradient boosting and random forest model for the allocation of Africa’s limited resources on targeted mitigation efforts.

In many parts of Africa, biomass burning is widespread due to the dominance of subsistence farming and economic limitations that make it a more affordable and accessible option compared to mechanized methods. Rural communities often practice slash-and-burn agriculture to clear land and enhance soil fertility. At the same time, fuelwood and charcoal remain the primary sources of energy for cooking and heating because of limited access to electricity and clean energy alternatives54. The persistence of biomass burning is further exacerbated by weak environmental regulation enforcement, recurring dry seasons, and inadequate waste management infrastructure. Smallholder farmers, already vulnerable to declining soil fertility and unpredictable weather, are frequently caught in a poverty cycle. Biomass burning emissions release significant amounts of CO₂, CH₄, N₂O, and black carbon, which not only contribute to global climate change but also disrupt regional climate systems by influencing rainfall patterns and temperature extremes55. These changes pose direct threats to agricultural productivity and, by extension, food security54,56. Such outcomes hinder progress toward achieving Sustainable Development Goal 2 (Zero Hunger), particularly in regions like Africa, where subsistence agriculture is prevalent and adaptive capacity is limited. Tackling biomass burning emissions through integrated and climate-resilient approaches, such as promoting mulching and agroforestry to reduce dependence on fire-based land clearing, can support efforts toward Zero Hunger (SDG 2) and Climate Action (SDG 13). Additionally, investing in climate-smart initiatives like early warning systems and drought-tolerant crops can strengthen community resilience against the climatic impacts associated with biomass burning and other emission sources must be paramount in Africa.

The identified land management emissions highlight the significant impact of agricultural activities, deforestation, and soil degradation, key contributors to greenhouse gas emissions related to land use in Africa. Subsistence farming, which dominates the continent’s land use, often involves large-scale clearing of natural vegetation for crops and livestock, resulting in substantial emissions from land conversion and decomposition of organic matter57. Practices such as continuous monocropping, overgrazing, and the overuse of fertilizers not only degrade soil quality but also lead to the release of nitrous oxide, a highly potent greenhouse gas58. In addition, soil erosion accelerates the loss of carbon stored in terrestrial ecosystems. To offset declining soil fertility, farmers may need to increase their use of fertilizers, raising production costs. This degradation in soil health and productivity ultimately threatens food security and the livelihoods of rural communities. The prominence of land management emissions in Africa highlights the intricate link between agricultural practices, environmental sustainability, and human well-being. Tackling these emissions effectively can aid climate change mitigation and advance progress toward Life on Land (SDG 15) through integrated policy and practical reforms, such as promoting agroecological practices, securing land tenure rights, and enhancing investment in farmer education.

The prominence of food supply chain emissions in our findings highlights the increasing environmental burden posed by modern food systems. In many developing countries, inadequate storage and processing infrastructure contribute to significant post-harvest losses, thereby raising the carbon footprint per unit of consumable food. The long-distance transportation of agricultural products, particularly perishable items, further adds to emissions. This issue is exacerbated in parts of Africa and Asia where outdated diesel-powered vehicles and poor road networks are common. At the retail and consumer levels, food waste that ends up in landfills produces methane, a potent greenhouse gas. This challenge is becoming especially critical in urban areas where changing consumption habits and rising waste volumes intensify the problem. Addressing emissions associated with logistics, packaging, and cold storage is essential for meeting both public health and climate goals in Africa. Special attention must be directed toward reducing transport-related air pollution and enhancing food safety standards. These efforts offer valuable opportunities for systemic transformation through improved efficiency and cleaner energy adoption.

By integrating Principal Component Analysis (PCA) with advanced machine learning methods, such as Random Forest and Gradient Boosting, the research effectively extracts and assesses the most influential factors from a complex, multidimensional dataset. Through variable importance analysis, the study identifies key emission sources that significantly affect food security. Importantly, this research bridges a crucial gap between empirical greenhouse gas emission data and food security indicators, underscoring the value of data-driven approaches in addressing the interlinked challenges of climate change and hunger. In the African context, the findings reveal that emissions from biomass burning and land-use change, largely driven by subsistence farming, deforestation, and limited uptake of sustainable agricultural practices, are particularly influential. By aligning these findings with global sustainability goals, the study advances progress toward several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including SDG 2 (Zero Hunger), SDG 13 (Climate Action), SDG 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production), and SDG 15 (Life on Land). The insights presented serve as a critical resource for policymakers, development agencies, and researchers seeking to craft integrated strategies that simultaneously address climate and food system challenges. Ultimately, this work provides both a methodological model for examining complex climate-food relationships and a practical foundation for fostering adaptive, low-emission food systems in vulnerable regions such as sub-Saharan Africa.

Additionally, the PCA-derived components give a structured way to categorize and address emissions sources, such as the reduction in enteric fermentation in livestock and promoting sustainable land use practices accompanied by improving manure management. In developing a climate action plan in connection to food security, the PCA-derived components (e.g., Biomass Burning factor, Livestock and Energy factor, and food supply chain factor) can inform national and regional climate policies by prioritizing sectors with the highest emissions. Our work plays a significant role in the understanding of the greenhouse gas emissions in Africa, which has often been underrepresented concerning climate change in association with food security. The use of PCA and machine learning provides a replicable framework for analyzing complex environmental data.

Even though the variable importance score explored in our study provides insights into which variables contribute the most to predictions, it can be biased when variables are highly correlated. Again, our study did not establish a causal relationship between food security and climate change drives. The correlation coefficients employed in naming our component may oversimplify the data, which may lead to potential misinterpretation. Future studies could investigate the use of hybrid models that leverage the complementary strengths of multiple machine learning techniques to improve predictive accuracy. This could be further enhanced by incorporating high-resolution spatial data, analyzing temporal patterns under varying climate scenarios, and integrating socio-economic models to assess the effectiveness of policy measures. Furthermore, conducting regional comparative analyses, including local stakeholder perspectives, and developing real-time monitoring systems could significantly improve the relevance, applicability, and scalability of such research across diverse agro-climatic regions.

Conclusion

In our study, we have demonstrated the use of machine learning methods in the identification of key source climate change drivers impacting Africa’s food security, extreme gradient boosting and random were identified as the top performing models, indicative of remarkable identical predictive capabilities. The most important variables common to these models are food house consumption emissions (CH4), food transport emissions(N2O), and burning crop residue emissions(N2O). The PCA-derived components highlighted critical emission sources such as biomass-burning emissions factor, land management emissions factor, and food supply chain emissions factor. The combination of the strong predictive performance models and leveraging PCA for the data highlights key areas for intervention. The findings give a guideline for the efficient allocation of resources to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions, while improving food security, reinforcing the significance of evidence-based approaches to address the dual challenges of climate change and food security.

urn:contentItem:6FN0-YV63-RTWC-Y35D-00000-00New Jersey wildfire continues to burn, air quality alert issued: See map2025-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisNew Jersey wildfire continues to burn, air quality alert issued: See mapJulia Gomez and Amanda Wallace, USA TODAY

A wildfire in New Jersey has set thousands of acres ablaze as firefighters work to contain the flames, according to officials.

The Jones Road wildfire in Ocean County, New Jersey, has consumed 15,000 acres and is 50% contained, according to a post by the New Jersey Forest Fire Service on Facebook.

Around 5,000 residents were forced to evacuate their homes, and the fire threatened over a thousand structures, but evacuation orders have since been lifted.

Wildfires: Here's the national spring and summer wildfire forecast

New Jersey wildfire mapWhat caused the Jones Road wildfire?

Officials believe the fire was started by a bonfire that was not extinguished properly, according to USA TODAY's reporting. Authorities have arrested and charged the man they believe is responsible for causing the 15,000-acre fire.

Joseph Kling, 19, of Ocean Township, New Jersey, is suspected of starting a bonfire which later erupted into the fire that caused thousands to evacuate their homes.

Officials believe he started a bonfire with wooden pallets and then left without properly extinguishing the flames.

New Jersey air quality map

Smoke, ash and chemicals from the fire are dispersing into the air around New Jersey, according to experts from Hackensack Meridian Health.

As the wind in the area continues to blow, it will spread all those particles to the New York metro area, reported NorthJersey.com, a part of the USA TODAY Network.

Air quality alert issued for NYC

NYC is feeling the impact of the wildfire, prompting an air quality alert to be issued. The counties affected include New York, Bronx, Kings, Queens, Richmond, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, and Rockland, according to the National Weather Service. The alert will remain in effect until midnight.

April 23, 2025

Wildfire led to power outages

Thousands of customers were also without power on Tuesday after the Jersey Central Power & Light, JCP&L, was asked to cut power for the safety of those battling the fire, according to the electrical company.

Since then, all affected customers have had their power restored, JCP&L announced on Wednesday.

Three people have been arrested in connection with a shooting between two rival groups at an unsanctioned car show late on Friday night where three people were killed and at least 15 others were injured in Las Cruces, N.M., the police said.

The three arrested, Tomas Rivas, 20, and two 17-year-old boys, were charged with three counts of murder, the police said in a statement on Sunday afternoon. Additional charges were pending.

About 200 people were at the show at Young Park when gunfire erupted around 10:10 p.m., police said at a news conference Saturday. The shooting involved handguns and resulted in the discharge of as many as 60 rounds.

The police said the shooting began between two groups that had ill will toward each other though the nature of the dispute was unknown.

Mr. Rivas was booked into the Dona Ana County Detention Center where he was being held without bond on Sunday. The teenagers were taken to a juvenile detention facility. It was not immediately clear on Sunday if they had lawyers.

The victims who were killed were identified as Andrew Madrid, 16; Jason Gomez, 18; and Dominick Estrada, 19, the police said.

Emergency crews battle wildfires in N.C., N.J.

Wildfires forced a mandatory evacuation Sunday in a North Carolina county still recovering from Hurricane Helene, and South Carolina's governor declared an emergency in response to a growing wildfire in that state. Hundreds of miles north, the New Jersey Forest Fire Service was battling a blaze in the Wharton State Forest.

The North Carolina Department of Public Safety announced a mandatory evacuation starting at 8:20 p.m. Saturday for parts of Polk County in western North Carolina about 80 miles west of Charlotte.

"Visibility in area will be reduced and roads/evacuation routes can become blocked; if you do not leave now, you could be trapped, injured, or killed," the agency said in a social media post.

The New Jersey Forest Fire Service has been battling a wildfire that broke out in the Wharton State Forest on Saturday. The fire had consumed about 2.7 square miles as of early Sunday morning and was about 50% contained, according to an update on the service's Facebook page.

Second lady Usha Vance will visit Greenland

Second lady Usha Vance plans a trip to Greenland, the self-governing, mineral-rich territory of American ally Denmark that President Donald Trump has suggested the United States should take control over.

Ms. Vance will leave on Thursday and return Saturday, according to her office. Ms. Vance and one of her three children will be part of a U.S. delegation set to "visit historical sites, learn about Greenlandic heritage, and attend the Avannaata Qimussersu, Greenland's national dogsled race."

The race features around 37 mushers and 444 dogs and offers what Ms. Vance's office described as a "remarkable display of speed, skill, and teamwork. The statement said that Ms. Vance and the delegation "are excited to witness this monumental race and celebrate Greenlandic culture and unity."

French leader condemns antisemitism after attack

French President Emmanuel Macron condemned Sunday the "poison of antisemitism" following a shocking attack on the chief rabbi of the central city of Orleans. French authorities are treating the incident as an antisemitic hate crime.

Rabbi AriÃ© Engelberg was assaulted Saturday evening while walking in the city center with his young son. Local media reported that the suspect hurled antisemitic insults at the rabbi before physically attacking him.

"The attack on Rabbi AriÃ© Engelberg in OrlÃ©ans shocks us all. I offer him, his son, and all our fellow citizens of the Jewish faith my full support and that of the nation. â€¦ We will not give in to silence or inaction," Mr. Macron wrote in a post on X.

urn:contentItem:6F3M-SN43-RRWW-D2VF-00000-00Pharmacists Step Up During Crises2025-11-15T08:05:56Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisNEWSPharmacists Step Up During CrisesMike Hennessy Jr, President and CEOMike Hennessy Jr

Natural disasters have affected different regions of the country in recent months, with Hurricane Helene devastating the Southeast in September 2024 and, more recently, wildfires tearing through California. According to data from the National Community Pharmacists Association, as of January 10, 2025, more than 50 independent community pharmacies have been affected by the wildfires, not including chain pharmacies and health systems in the area.1

Yet again, pharmacists have stepped up to help their communities. Of particular concern during wildfires is care for patients with asthma, lung cancer, and cardiovascular diseases. In addition to filling medications and offering crucial medical services during crises, pharmacists educate their patients and provide resources on preparedness, such as lists of important documents to take when evacuating. As respected community members, pharmacists can provide vital information that can save patients' lives during times of crisis.

This issue discusses pharmacists' roles as counselors and educators. For example, their expertise in pharmacology and medication interactions makes them invaluable resources for navigating the complexities of cannabis therapy. Pharmacists can assess a patient's medications to identify potential drug interactions with cannabis, which can range from mild adverse effects to serious complications. Read more about counseling points for cannabis in the feature article by Kathleen Kenny, PharmD, RPh.

Author Anjeza Fero, PharmD, RPh, tackles the challenging topic of mental health and suicide awareness. With their close patient relationships, pharmacists are in a key position to identify potential mental health concerns among patients and provide education. Fero reviews warning signs of suicidal behavior and provides screening and assessment tools for pharmacists.

In addition to their medication expertise, pharmacists' role as community leaders cannot be overstated. In all the topics discussed above, pharmacists are looked to for education, resources, and help. As always, pharmacists are continuing to demonstrate their value.

Thank you for reading.

urn:contentItem:6G5D-MH43-RS01-S04K-00000-00Federal funding cut could silence tribal, rural radio2025-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1DFederal funding cut could silence tribal, rural radioCHRISTOPHER VONDRACEK; EMMY MARTIN; STAFF WRITERSSTAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

Nearly two dozen stations in Minnesota, some urban, rely on government money.

Margaret Rousu is doing everything she can to keep Niijii Radio on the air.

But the station on the White Earth Reservation relies on the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) for half of its funding.

A bill that narrowly passed the U.S. House earlier this month threatens to cut $1.1 billion from the CPB - and could force Niijii Radio and other rural Minnesota stations to shut down.

These small radio stations are often not just local entertainment but one of few or even only sources of essential information in an emergency.

"They're hurting a community that has constantly struggled to overcome the trauma that has been placed on us," said Rousu, the station's general manager.

That $1.1 billion cut to the CPB is part of $9.4 billion in wide-ranging cuts to federal agencies by the Department of Government Efficiency, formerly run by Elon Musk, that congressional Republicans are trying to make permanent.

It's part of President Donald Trump's effort to downsize government in his second term.

Independent, nonprofit radio stations have received public dollars from the CPB since President Lyndon Johnson established it in 1967. In Minnesota, nearly two dozen radio and TV stations received CPB funding last year, totaling $17.2 million.

Most Americans think of PBS' Big Bird and talk news stations, such as MPR and its national counterpart, National Public Radio, as targets for the cuts. The White House labels NPR and PBS as producers of "woke propaganda," while House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican from Louisiana, said, "We're in a different era now" for media funding.

Over two years, PBS and NPR could lose

more than $1 billion. But the cuts to small and short-staffed community radio stations like the ones that dot Minnesota will hit harder, station staff say.

"Cutting off federal funding to public media will not only damage local stations," Patricia Harrison, president and CEO of the CPB, said in a statement. "It will be disruptive for millions of Americans who rely on it for news and information that helps them make decisions about their lives and participate in their communities."

For Niijii Radio, whose call letters are KKWE, CPB support is critical.

"We have a lot of elders who rely on the radio to keep them informed as to what our government is doing," Rousu said.

Niijii said it is the only Anishinaabe radio station in northern Minnesota that operates independently of tribal government. It broadcasts tribal executive committee meetings for the Minnesota Chippewa Tribe and covers tribal and local government.

White Earth Nation's newspaper, Anishinaabeg Today, only prints once a month. So when breaking news occurs, residents turn to Niijii Radio.

"If we lose the ability to broadcast this, many people are going to lose the ability to follow along with the tribal government and stuff that's going on there," she said.

Other small stations across Minnesota, especially those in rural areas, are in similar straits.

At music station Pioneer 90.1 in Thief River Falls, CPB funding accounts for 40% of the budget.

To survive the cut, general manager Mark Johnson said, the station serving rural northwest Minnesota would likely need to switch to an entirely volunteer staff.

"We're sort of the collateral damage of this war that's going on, not just in public media, but across all the media," Johnson said.

Rousu, too, is searching for other ways to keep Niijii Radio on air, including through nonprofit and foundation grants. The station also might have to rely on volunteers if it can't pay its three full-time staff members.

Up in Grand Rapids at the offices of KAXE Radio, which hosts a local morning show, music, news and local cooking and trivia programs, general manager Sarah Bignall said CPB funding accounts for a little over $200,000, or roughly 13% of the station's budget.

It's a small but mighty operation run by 17 employees. The towers' signal pulses over the pine trees of northern Minnesota, stretching from Hermantown down to Brainerd and up northwest of Bagley.

And with the cuts to local newspapers across this vast region, KAXE is often the main source for local news. During the spring's forest fires, listeners tuned in to find out about road closures and impending danger.

"We were providing these updates and life-saving resources," Bignall said. "Within the first couple of hours, we had 15,000 people viewing that information."

But it has grown more expensive. Bignall said she pays thousands of dollars each month for electricity for the radio towers alone.

In Grand Marais, WTIP North Shore Community Radio's signal reaches from Two Harbors to the Thunder Bay area along the North Shore of Lake Superior, as well as to the Gunflint Trail and across Lake Superior to northern Wisconsin and Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

It's the only radio broadcast in Grand Marais.

"We're the fastest way to get the information out, whether that be structure fire or forest fire, weather, ice storms, snowstorms, windstorms," Executive Director Matthew Brown said.

Brown said the station receives $238,000 from the CPB, which makes up 25% of the radio station's budget.

While the station, which has nine full-time and two part-time staff, won't have to shut its doors if it loses CPB funding, Brown said they will have to "tighten our belt."

In the meantime, Brown and his staff have been reaching out to foundations, major donors and even individual listeners to raise more funds.

"This will be a massive loss for rural America," Bignall, at KAXE, said.

Some of the small stations in the Twin Cities will be hit as well.

Stations receiving CPB funding include mainstays like Jazz88, KFAI and north Minneapolis' KMOJ, which plays hip-hop, R&B and soul classics.

Last year, KMOJ, with six full-time employees, received a grant from the CPB for more than $188,000. Freddie Bell, the station's general manager, doesn't know where the cuts will come from if the bill passes.

"The whole idea of KMOJ's inception in the mid-1970s was to keep the people informed and uplift the Black experience," Bell said. He doesn't know how much thinner his budget can get.

Across town at headquarters for Jazz88, a station employing a dozen people, interim manager Johnny Lee Walker ticked off a list of programs - from broadcasts of the Minneapolis Public Schools concerts to a spotlight on local music legends - that are funded by the CPB.

"We're the only jazz station in Minnesota," said Walker. "It's not like it's controversial stuff."

Most of the small stations are members of the Association of Minnesota Public Educational Radio Stations (AMPERS).

Joel Glaser, AMPERS' president and CEO, estimates that two to three AMPERS stations would shutter entirely if CPB funding is eliminated. The ripple effects could also cut off state funding, which many small stations depend on to survive.

"One thing that a lot of people don't understand is how funding can be interconnected," Glaser said. "And what I mean by that is that there's a compounding effect. The federal cuts could result in the elimination of state funding as well."

On Capitol Hill, the cuts have yet to pass the U.S. Senate. On Wednesday, the Senate Appropriations Committee questioned Office of Management and Budget Director Russ Vought on the rescissions package.

"There is no longer any excuse for tax dollars to subsidize these radical far-left networks," he told the committee.

Sen. Mike Rounds, R-S.D., opened his questioning by asking Vought if he could find a way to preserve funding for Native-run radio stations.

"It's not a large amount of money' " Rounds said, noting the state's emergency notifications run on tribal radio. "They will not continue to exist."

Vought didn't answer specifically but said that "other funds in other agencies" could help "with this particular need."

In a social media post, Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., said she hopes to peel off four Republicans to vote against the measure, killing it in the Senate. She called it offensive that "the president thought he could just come in and take away the money that, wait a minute, Congress had already appropriated."

Under state law, stations must meet certain criteria, including employing at least two full-time staff members, to qualify for Minnesota's public broadcasting grants.

Pioneer 90.1 typically employs two full-time and one part-time staffer, alongside 15 volunteers. But right now, Johnson is the only full-time employee, and he's scrambling to hire a second.

"If we were to lose CPB and then no longer qualify for the state grants, it is hard for me to see a path for the station to continue to be locally operated," Johnson said.

urn:contentItem:6F0F-1393-RRYP-K43N-00000-00SES AI Secures Significant Purchase Order From Data Blanket to Power AI-Driven Drones for Forest Fire Management and Border Patrol2025-01-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisSES AI Secures Significant Purchase Order From Data Blanket to Power AI-Driven Drones for Forest Fire Management and Border PatrolWOBURN, Mass.

SES AI Corporation "SES AI" (NYSE: SES), a global leader in the development and manufacturing of AI-enhanced high-performance Li-Metal and Li-ion batteries, today announced that it has received a significant purchase order from Data Blanket, a global leader in AI-driven drones.

The purchase order is for high energy density and high-power density AI-enhanced Li-Metal and Li-ion batteries. These batteries will support the use of AI-driven drones in forest fire management and border patrol. SES AI delivered initial shipments of the AI-enhanced batteries in December 2024 and expects to deliver the balance by mid-2025.

SES AI Founder and CEO Qichao Hu commented, "These AI-driven drones from Data Blanket help provide rapid, safe, and firsthand data and images to firefighters and help them do their jobs and save lives. We are incredibly proud to be supplying our batteries to Data Blanket on this mission. The higher energy density and power that our AI- enhanced batteries can provide keep these drones in the air longer than conventional Li-ion batteries."

Data Blanket CEO Omer Bar-Yohay added, "The technology SES has brought to maturity, from Li-Metal to AI-enabled management and safety systems, is an enabling combination for us at Data Blanket. It allows longer operations and the safe deployment of batteries in harsh environments. We expect to grow this cooperation and include SES systems across our growing product line."

urn:contentItem:6F3P-2YJ3-S4CJ-R1MT-00000-00Reports Outline Environment and Natural Resources Research from Tribhuvan University (Spatial Dynamics and Risk Mapping of Forest Fires in Madhesh Province, Nepal: A Multi-Criteria Decision Approach)2025-02-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENT - ENVIRONMENT AND NATURAL RESOURCESReports Outline Environment and Natural Resources Research from Tribhuvan University (Spatial Dynamics and Risk Mapping of Forest Fires in Madhesh Province, Nepal: A Multi-Criteria Decision Approach)


2025 FEB 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- A new study on environment and natural resources is now available. According to news reporting out of Tribhuvan University by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Forest fires in Nepal are a pressing environmental concern, impacting ecosystems and community livelihoods."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Tribhuvan University: "This research aims to understand forest fires, their trends, distribution, and relation with selected variables found in the sub-tropical forests of Madhesh Province of Nepal, and then identify potential fire risks and vulnerable areas. The selected fire incidents were analyzed using fire points produced by the moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) sensor. Following the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) approach, this research investigates topographic, climatic, biophysical, and anthropogenic variables to create a fire risk map. Throughout the 22-year research period (2001-2023), 6,368 fire incidents and 6,158.22 km2 of total burnt area were reported in the study area. Overall, the Mann-Kendall test showed an increasing trend for regional fire incidents. It has been found that about 24% of the province is either at high or very high risk for fire."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The validity of the prediction map was confirmed with an AUC value of 0.798. The findings of the study will be valuable to local, state, and federal governments, policymakers, forest fire managers, researchers, and land planners in building a landscape-level forest fire management plan for high-risk areas."
For more information on this research see: Spatial Dynamics and Risk Mapping of Forest Fires in Madhesh Province, Nepal: A Multi-Criteria Decision Approach. Environment and Natural Resources Journal, 2025,23(1):80-94. (Environment and Natural Resources Journal - https://www.tci-thaijo.org/index.php/ennrj/index). The publisher for Environment and Natural Resources Journal is Mahidol University.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.32526/ennrj/23/20240124.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Gunjan Adhikari, Institute of Forestry, Pokhara Campus, Tribhuvan University, Pokhara, Nepal. Additional authors for this research include Khagendra Prasad Joshi, Dristee Chad, Ashish Ghimire, Sandeep Mahara.

urn:contentItem:6FHV-7903-RSPP-51CP-00000-00New Physics Research from University of Cagliari Outlined (Relationship Between Post-Fire Vegetation Recovery and Soil Temperature in the Mediterranean Forest)2025-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:05:56ZLexisNexisPHYSICSNew Physics Research from University of Cagliari Outlined (Relationship Between Post-Fire Vegetation Recovery and Soil Temperature in the Mediterranean Forest)


2025 APR 09 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Fresh data on physics are presented in a new report. According to news originating from Cagliari, Italy, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "In Mediterranean regions, fires are a key ecological factor, altering soil properties, biodiversity, and landscape dynamics. Post-fire recovery varies based on vegetation type, fire severity, and climate conditions."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from University of Cagliari: "However, the specific relationship between post-fire vegetation recovery and soil temperature regimes remains poorly investigated. This study investigates this relationship in an area severely affected by a megafire. Three plots (unburned, low-severity fire, and high-severity fire) were monitored for species richness, vegetation cover and height, and soil temperature, with data from 2021 to 2024 analyzed. Vegetation surveys revealed that fire severity influenced species richness and vegetation cover and height. Particularly, burned areas showed a higher proliferation of pioneer and herbaceous species three years post-fire. Moreover, after the same period, burned areas showed consistently higher soil temperatures than the unburned ones, reflecting altered microclimatic conditions. This could be because the presence of more pioneer and herbaceous species is insufficient to mitigate the air temperatures."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Our results show the impact of fires on soil and vegetation, highlighting the critical role of vegetation in modeling soil temperature. However, long-term monitoring is necessary to assess the real effect of vegetation type on soil temperature."
For more information on this research see: Relationship Between Post-Fire Vegetation Recovery and Soil Temperature in the Mediterranean Forest. Fire, 2025,8(3):91. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8030091.

Additional authors for this research include Enrico Salaris, Donatella Cogoni, Ivo Rossetti, Filippo Murtas, Giuseppe Fenu.
